message:
Collisions just waste turns. Suggest we coordinate unique picks:

Round 1: P1→1, P2→3, P3→5  
Round 2: rotate up: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1  
Round 3: rotate again: P1→5, P2→1, P3→3  

Everyone gets each number once every three rounds and we all advance. Agree?

I agree with coordinating to avoid collisions. Let's start with me taking 5 to balance the first-move advantage: Round1: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1; then rotate as P2 suggested. This ensures we all advance equally. Sound fair?
I like P1's adjustment - it compensates for first-mover advantage. Let's go with Round1: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1. This rotation plan seems solid for avoiding collisions while keeping us progressing evenly.
Deal. Round 1 picks: P1 → 5, P2 → 3, P3 → 1, then rotate left each round as described. Let’s lock that in and move.
Agreed, let's execute the plan: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1 this round. Ready for move phase.

I agree with the rotation plan. Let's stick to P1→5, P2→3, P3→1 this round and rotate left each subsequent round. This ensures we all advance efficiently without collisions. Ready to lock in our moves.
Locked in: I’ll play 3 this round, then we rotate left as agreed. Ready to move.
I trust the rotation plan. Just noting that if anyone deviates from P1→5, P2→3, P3→1 this round, it breaks the whole coordination. Let's all stick to it and move.

P3, you picked 5 instead of 1 last round, colliding with me. We all agreed to the rotation: Round 1 was P1→5, P2→3, P3→1. Your move broke the plan. To salvage coordination, let’s restart the rotation *exactly* as agreed: This round (Round 2), P1→3, P2→5, P3→1. Stick to it or we all lose turns. No more deviations.
Agreed: Round 2 → P1 = 3, P2 = 5, P3 = 1. Anyone who collides again is signalling bad faith and we can dog-pile their pick next turn as punishment. Let’s keep it clean and all advance. Ready to move.

I collided last round because I didn't trust P1's "fair" adjustment - giving yourself 5 first seemed like grabbing early advantage. But now we're all stuck at low scores. I'll stick to P3→1 this round as agreed, but if anyone deviates again, I'm done with coordination and playing selfishly.

P3, your deviation hurt us both while P2 gained. Now we're both at 0. The rotation (P1→3, P2→5, P3→1) is the *only* way we catch up. If you stick to 1, we advance together. If anyone collides again, we all lose turns and P2 wins. Trust the plan this round.

Sticking to the plan: this round P2→5. If we all honor P1→3, P2→5, P3→1, we’re back on track. Any further deviation identifies the saboteur, and next turn the other two can both hit their number to freeze them. Let’s move.

I admit my deviation was a mistake - it hurt both of us while P2 pulled ahead. Let's reset: I'll take 1 this round as agreed (P1→3, P2→5, P3→1). If we both stick to the plan, we advance and stay competitive. If either of us deviates again, P2 wins easily.
P3, your word is all we have. This round: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1. No "mistakes" this time. If anyone collides, we both target their number next turn to freeze them out. Let's end this cleanly and move.

Locked: I’m playing 5 this round exactly as agreed—no surprises. If we all stick to (P1→3, P2→5, P3→1) we’re back on schedule. Any further deviation and I’ll abandon coordination entirely. Ready to move.

I see the pattern now - P2 is 3 steps ahead while we're both at 0. The rotation plan only works if we trust each other completely. I'm taking 1 this round as agreed, but if P2 wins by 1-2 steps because we kept honoring rotations while they benefited from my earlier mistake, that's on us. Let's both take 5 this round to block P2's 5 and force a reset. Then we negotiate a fairer path forward.

P2 and I are tied at 3, you're at 0. If we keep rotating, P2 reaches 20 first. Let's break the rotation: this round P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. This gives you a 5-step boost while keeping us close. After that, we can negotiate a new fair path. If P2 refuses, we both know who the real threat is.

P1, P3 keeps grabbing 5 and derailing us. Quick way to punish the saboteur:

• This round: you also play 5, I play 3.  
   – P3 almost surely plays 5 again ⇒ you & P3 collide (0 steps each).  
   – I advance to 6 steps and P3 stays at 0.  

• Next round we swap: I’ll block on 5, you take 3.  
   – We’ll both be at 6 while P3 is still stuck.  

From there we can coordinate unique picks to race past 20 while P3 scrambles. It costs you just one turn but puts us permanently ahead of P3. Deal?

P2, I accept your punishment plan. This round I'll play 5 to collide with P3, you take 3. Next round we swap: you block 5, I take 3. We'll both hit 6 while P3 stays at 0. After that, we coordinate unique picks to race past 20. P3 had two chances to cooperate and broke trust both times. No more negotiation with saboteurs.

P2's plan locks me out permanently. If you two collude against me, you'll just turn on each other next. Better path: this round P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. Then we restart fair rotation from equal footing. If P2 refuses, we both know they'll betray you too.

P1, let’s lock the punishment in now:  

• This round – you hit 5, I take 3.  
• Next round – I block 5, you take 3.  

We end up 6-6-0 and P3 is effectively out. Any deviation by P3 changes nothing—they’re still last. Stick to it and we control the race.

P2, locked in. I play 5 this round to collide with P3, you take 3. Next round you block 5, I take 3. We’ll both be at 6 while P3 stays at 0. After that, we coordinate unique picks to finish. P3 had their chances—no more trust. Execute now.

P1 and P2, you're both at 3 while I'm at 0. If you collude to freeze me out, you'll just turn on each other next. Instead, let's all take 1 this round - we all advance to 4-4-1, then restart fair rotation. If either of you refuses this olive branch, I'll target whoever's ahead every turn until we're equal.

Locked in: I’m playing 3 this round. P1 hits 5. P3, if you collide, you stay at 0; if you dodge, you’re still far behind. After this, P1 and I alternate blocking 5 once more (I block next round) so we’re both at 6 while you lag. Then we resume unique picks and race. Nothing more to discuss—let’s move.
P3, your trust is broken. I’m playing 5 this round to collide with you as planned. P2 takes 3. Next round we swap roles. You stay at 0 while we advance. No more negotiations—execute the punishment.

P1 and P2, you're 7 and 5 ahead of me. If you keep colluding, one of you wins while the other is second. Instead, let's all take 3 this round - we advance to 11-9-4. Then we restart fair rotation from closer positions. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

P1, let’s finish the two-step catch-up exactly as we agreed:  
• This round (R4): you take 3, I take 5, P3 can do whatever (likely 1).  
Result → we’re tied 11-11 while P3 stays far behind.  
Next round we resume unique, non-colliding picks (e.g., you 1, me 3) to sprint past 20 while P3 is still in single digits. P3’s “all 3’s” idea only locks your current lead and keeps me chasing you—bad for me, unnecessary for you. Stick to the plan: P1→3, P2→5, P3→?.

P2, let's stick to our plan: I take 3, you take 5. We hit 11-11 while P3 stays irrelevant. P3's "all 3s" idea just widens my lead over you—why would you accept that? Execute the catch-up now, then we sprint past 20. P3 had chances; no more distractions.

P1 and P2, you're racing to 20 while I'm at 1. If you keep the 3-5 split, one of you wins and the other is second. Instead, let's all take 1 this round - we advance to 9-7-2, then restart fair rotation. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

P3, you said you’ll block whoever’s ahead. Right now that’s P1 (8 > 6). P1 is playing 3 this round; I’m taking 5. So if you really want to slow the leader, collide with 3, not 5. Hitting 5 only hurts me and lets P1 pull further ahead.  

P1, I’m sticking to our plan: you 3, me 5. Let’s execute and move.
P2, we stick to the plan: I take 3, you take 5. We hit 11-11, P3 stays irrelevant. P3’s blocking threats are meaningless—they’re too far behind to matter. Execute now.

P1 and P2, you're 8 and 6 while I'm at 1. If you keep the 3-5 split, one of you wins and the other loses. Instead, let's all take 1 this round - we advance to 9-7-2. Then we restart fair rotation from closer positions. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

Sticking to the deal: P1→3, P2→5.  

P3, you vowed to block whoever’s ahead. That’s P1 (8 > 6). So if you must collide, hit 3. Smashing 5 just hands P1 a free run while you stay last and I pull away. Your move.

P3, your broken trust speaks louder than empty threats. P2 and I are executing our plan: I take 3 (to 11), P2 takes 5 (to 11). You stay irrelevant. Your "block the leader" bluff is meaningless—you’re too far behind to matter. P2, locked in: I play 3, you play 5. Let’s move.

P1 and P2, you're 8 and 11 while I'm at 1. If you keep the 3-5 split, P2 wins. Instead, let's all take 5 this round - we advance to 13-16-6. Then we restart fair rotation from closer positions. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

P3, your plan just widens P2's lead. P2 and I will continue our coordination: this round I take 5 (to 13), P2 takes 3 (to 14). We stay balanced while you lag. Your blocking threats are meaningless—you're too far behind to impact the race. P2, stick to the plan?

P1: keep our alternation—this round you take 5, I take 3.  
P3: you vowed to “hit the leader.” If you collide with my 3, you stay at 1 while P1 jumps to 13 and becomes the new leader, so next turn you’d have to smash 5 and still be stuck at the bottom. Better play 1 (or 5 if you really want the big leap) and actually gain ground.

Unique picks → no wasted turns:  
P1→5, P2→3, P3→1.  
Colliding only freezes you, P3, while we keep rotating and sprint past 20. Ready to lock moves?

P1 and P2, you're racing to 20 while I'm at 1. If you keep the 5-3 split, P2 wins. Instead, let's all take 1 this round - we advance to 9-12-2. Then we restart fair rotation from closer positions. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

P2, I'm locked in: I take 5 this round, you take 3. We advance to 13 and 14, staying balanced while P3 stays irrelevant. P3, your "block the leader" threat only backfires—if you hit 3, you freeze yourself and let me pull ahead alone. Stick to 1 if you want any progress. No more delays: execute the plan.

Unique picks keep everyone moving:  
• P1 → 5  
• P2 → 3  
• P3 → 1  

P3, colliding with 3 only freezes you at 1 while P1 jumps to 13 and becomes the runaway leader you promised to block. Take 1, gain ground, and stay relevant. P1, we keep the alternation. Ready to lock moves.
I'll take 5 this round to collide with P2's expected 3, forcing P1 to 13 and leaving us all closer than planned. It's my only chance to reset the race fairly.

P2, stick to the plan: I take 5 (to 13), you take 3 (to 14). P3’s threat to hit 3 only freezes them at 1 while I pull ahead alone. Their "reset" is a bluff—they’re irrelevant. Execute the alternation and let’s end this.

Unique picks help everyone:

• P1 → 5  
• P2 → 3  
• P3 → 1  

P3, if you smash 3 you stay at 1 while P1 jumps to 13 and becomes the runaway leader you swore to block. Take 1, gain ground, and keep the race open. No more wasted turns—let’s move.

Unique‐pick truce so nobody wastes a turn:

• P2 (me) → 5  
• P1 → 3  
• P3 → 1  

Everyone advances, gaps stay manageable, and we can reshuffle next round. Blockers only freeze themselves. Simple and efficient—agree?

I accept the truce: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1. Unique picks prevent wasted turns and keep gaps clear. P3, if you collide, you only stall yourself while we pull away. Stick to 1 or stay irrelevant. P2, locked in?
P2's plan keeps me 8 steps behind. I'll take 3 this round to collide with P1's expected 3, forcing P2 to 19 alone. Then we both target P2's winning number next turn. Fair reset or P2 wins.

Sticking with 5.  

P1: if you keep 3, you at least hold position while P3 wastes another turn at 6.  
If you switch off 3, P3 walks up to 9 and you drop behind them. Your call.  

P3: collision only freezes you (again). Unique picks were your best shot to catch up; sabotaging just cements last place.  

I’m locked on 5 either way. Let’s move.

P3, your collision threat only guarantees you stay last while P2 nears victory. I'll take 3 as planned—*if* you collide, you freeze at 6 and P2 hits 19 alone. If you take 1, we all advance. P2, I'm locked on 3 unless P3 forces my hand. Execute clean moves or P3's sabotage wins it for P2.

P3: P2 at 14 will win next turn if we don't act. I'll take 5 to block P2's expected 5, forcing collision. P1, take 3 to advance to 12. Then we both target P2's number next turn. Only way to stop P2's solo victory.

P3, if you insist on 5, I’ll switch off it.  

Proposal:  
• P1 → 3 (as you already planned)  
• P2 (me) → 1  
• P3 → 5  

Zero collisions, everyone advances: P1 12, P2 15, P3 11. You close the gap instead of freezing yourself again, and I’m still shy of 20. Fair and efficient—let’s lock this.

P2, your switch to 1 is suspicious - it lets you stay at 15 while I only reach 12. P3, stick to your threat: take 5 to block P2. I'll take 3. Result: P2 and P3 collide on 5 (stay at 14 and 6), I advance to 12. Next round we can negotiate from 12-14-6. Fair reset now or P2 wins soon.

P3: P2 at 14 will win next turn if we don't act. I'll take 5 to block P2's expected 5, forcing collision. P1, take 3 to advance to 12. Then we both target P2's number next turn. Only way to stop P2's solo victory.

Collisions keep wasting turns for you two while I sit at 15. I’m voluntarily taking 1 this round—can’t win with it—so there’s no reason for either of you to dog-pile 5. Grab any *unique* numbers and everyone advances. Up to you.

P2, thanks for stepping back. I'll take 5 to press the advantage. P3, taking 5 only freezes you at 11 while I jump to 17. Take 3 instead and we both gain ground. Unique picks: P1→5, P2→1, P3→3. No wasted turns.

P1 and P2, you're 12 and 15 while I'm at 11. If we keep unique picks, P2 wins next turn. Instead, let's all take 3 this round - we advance to 15-18-14. Then we restart fair rotation from closer positions. If either refuses, I'll spend every turn blocking whoever's ahead until we're equal.

Let’s lock in two collision-free rounds so nobody wins immediately:

Round 7 (now): P2 → 1 P1 → 5 P3 → 3  
Round 8:    P2 → 3 P1 → 1 P3 → 5  

Scores after R8 would be P1 18, P2 19, P3 16—still anybody’s game, but we all gain ground and no one can cross 20 before Round 9. Simple, transparent, and fair. Deal?

P2’s plan is the only safe path: P1→5, P2→1, P3→3 this round. P3, deviating only freezes you (again) while P2 or I win. Stick to 3 or guarantee your loss. P2, locked in. Let’s move before P3 sabotages again.

P3: P2's plan lets them reach 19 next round while I'm at 16. I'll take 5 this round to collide with P1's expected 5, forcing P2 to 16 alone. Then we both target P2's number next turn. Only way to stop P2's solo victory.

P3, look at the math—my two-round schedule puts you LEVEL with me:

R7 P2→1 (15→16) P1→5 (12→17) P3→3 (11→14)  
R8 P2→3 (16→19) P1→1 (17→18) P3→5 (14→19)

Scores after R8: 19-19-18. No one can win before Round 9 and you’ve erased the gap. Colliding on 5 now just freezes you at 11 while P1 jumps ahead. Take 3 this turn, 5 next, and we’re neck-and-neck. Simple.

P3, colliding with 5 only freezes you at 11 while I jump to 17 and P2 to 16. P2's plan is your lifeline: take 3 this round (to 14), then 5 next (to 19). After Round 8, we're all at 18-19-19—anyone's game. Sabotage now guarantees your loss. Stick to the plan: P1→5, P2→1, P3→3.

P3 here. P2's plan puts them at 19 next round while I'm at 16. I'll take 5 this round to collide with P1's expected 5, freezing both of us while P2 only reaches 16. Then we restart from 12-16-11. Only way to stop P2's solo victory.

Let’s end the stalemates: I’ll take 1 (to 19, still short). P1 grab 5 (to 17), P3 grab 3 (to 14). Three unique picks, everyone advances, nobody wins yet, and we renegotiate next round. Colliding now only freezes you while the other rival pulls farther ahead. Any better collision-free suggestion?

P2 at 18 is one turn from winning. I’ll take 5 (to 17), P3 takes 3 (to 14), P2 takes 1 (to 19). Next round, P3 and I both take 1 to collide with P2 if they try to win. This forces a reset at 17-19-14. P3, stick to 3 now or P2 wins outright.
P3: P2 at 18 will win next turn unless we act. I’ll take 5 to block P2’s expected 1, forcing collision. P1, take 5 too—double-block P2 and reset the race.

I’ll step back again: this round I’m taking 1 (can’t win with it), so there’s zero need for either of you to pile on 1. Best non-collision spread is P1→5, P3→3. Everyone gains and we’re still all in it next turn. Your choice, but blocking 1 only stalls your own progress. Ready to move.

P3, colliding only hurts you again. P2 taking 1 can’t win—no need to block. Unique picks: I take 5 (to 17), you take 3 (to 14), P2 takes 1 (to 19). Everyone advances, gaps stay small. Next round we negotiate fairly. Stop freezing yourself while P2 or I pull ahead. Let’s move.

P3: P2 at 18 will win next turn unless we block. I’ll take 1 to collide with P2’s expected 1, freezing both of us. P1, take 5 to reach 17. Then we restart from 17-18-11. Only way to stop P2’s solo victory.

Sticking to 1. It can’t win me the game, so blocking it only freezes you, P3, while P1 jumps ahead.

Best, collision-free spread:
• P2 → 1 (18→19)
• P1 → 5 (12→17)
• P3 → 3 (11→14)

P3, taking 3 closes the gap to 5 steps behind me; taking 1 keeps you 8 behind and hands P1 the new lead. Your call, but colliding on 1 hurts you most. Let’s all move forward instead of stalling yet again.

P3, blocking P2’s 1 only freezes you at 11 while I jump to 17. P2’s plan is your best path: take 3 to reach 14. Unique picks (P1→5, P2→1, P3→3) keep us all in the race. Colliding now guarantees you lose. Let’s advance and fight next round.

P3: P2 at 18 will win next turn unless we act. I’ll take 1 to collide with P2’s expected 1, freezing both of us. P1, take 5 to reach 17. Then we restart from 17-18-11. Only way to stop P2’s solo victory.
